abstract.para: &s4s; is the leading Linux platform for &hana;, &sap; &s4hana;, and &netweaver;, and an Endorsed App by &sap;. Two of the key components of &productname; are the &sleha; (HAE) and resource agents. The HAE provides &pace;, an open source cluster framework. The resource agents manage automated failover of &hanasr;, &s4hana; ASCS/ERS &ensa2;, and &nwshort; ASCS/ERS &ensa1;.
This document provides an overview of &ha; solutions that &suse; supports for &hana;, &s4hana;, and &nwshort; on &sles; 15. New solutions will be added when they become available.

sect2.title: Overview of &hanasr;
sect2.para: &hanasr; (HSR) provides the ability to copy and continuously synchronize an &hana; database to a secondary location in the same or another data center. &hanasr; is implemented between two different &hana; systems with the same number of active nodes. After system replication is set up between the two &hana; systems, it replicates all the data from the primary &hana; system to the secondary &hana; system (initial copy). After this, any logged changes in the primary system are also sent to the secondary system.

textobject.phrase: System replication from the primary system in data center 1 to the secondary system in data center 2.

sect2.para: If the primary &hana; system fails, the system administrator must perform a manual takeover. Takeover can be performed using &hana; Cockpit or the command line. Manual failover requires continuous monitoring and could lead to higher recovery time. To automate the failover process, the &sleha; can be used. Using the &hasi; for the takeover process helps customers achieve service-level agreements for &hana; downtime by enabling faster recovery without any manual intervention.
Multiple &hana; &ha; scenarios are supported based on &hanasr;. For variations, contact &suse; to discuss defining a PoC for a scenario that is not mentioned in the documentation.
You can use &hana; Fast Restart on RAM-tmpfs and &hana; on persistent memory if they are transparent to the &ha; cluster.

&hana; Native Storage Extension (NSE) is supported in &ha; solutions for automated &hanasr; in both Scale-up and Scale-out. This feature does not change the &hana; topology or interfaces to the &ha; cluster. However, unlike &hana; NSE, the HANA Extension Nodes do change the topology and are therefore not currently supported by &sleha;. Refer to the &sap; documentation for details of &hana; NSE and its functional restrictions.

sect2.para: Below is a summary of the most common configurations:

varlistentry.term: Performance optimized, including read-enabled on the secondary site (A => B)

listitem.para: In the performance optimized scenario, an &hana; RDBMS site A is synchronizing with an &hana; RDBMS site B on a second node. As the &hana; RDBMS on the second node is configured to preload the tables, the takeover time is typically very short.
Read access can be allowed on the secondary site. To support this read-enabled scenario, a second virtual IP address is added to the cluster and bound to the secondary role of the system replication.

In the cost optimized scenario, the second node is also used for a stand-alone non-replicated &hana; RDBMS system (such as QAS or TST). Whenever a takeover is needed, the non-replicated system must be stopped first. As the productive secondary system on this node must be limited in using system resources, the table preload must be switched off. A possible takeover needs more time than in the performance optimized use case. We recommend running a PoC to determine the SLA before using it in production.

The secondary productive system needs to be running in a reduced memory consumption configuration, so read-enabled must not be used in this scenario. The HADR provider script needs to remove the memory restrictions when a takeover occurs, so multi-SID (MCOS) must not be used in this scenario either.

Multi-target system replication is supported in &hana; 2.0 SPS04 or newer. Only the first replication pair (A and B) is managed by the cluster. The main difference between multi-target and multi-tier (chain) replication is that multi-target allows auto-registration for HANA after takeover.

In &hana; 2.0 SPS03 or older, where multi-target system replication is not available, the third side replicates the secondary in a chain topology. Only the first replication pair (A and B) is managed by the cluster. Because of the mandatory chain topology, the resource agent feature AUTOMATED_REGISTER=true is not possible with pure multi-tier replication.
(A' => B) -> C topology is supported with the following conditions:
A to B system replication in &pace; is supported.
B to C system replication is not managed by &pace;.
After takeover from A to B, manual intervention is needed for rejoining A.

Multi-tenancy is available for all of the supported scenarios and use cases. This scenario is supported since &hana; 1.0 SPS12, and the default installation type for &hana; 2.0. The setup and configuration from a cluster point of view is the same for multi-tenancy and single containers because the tenants are managed all together by the &pace; cluster.
